ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the materials and techniques used by ancient Egyptians to produce various things from copper tools to food to clothing. I also learned more about experimental archaeology and methods used to reconstruct ancient methods of production.
It was a window into the chaines operatoires and uses of many materials by the Egyptians.
Knowledge of the materials and production processes of ancient Egypt

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I learned a lot about the various methods and techniques of production, especially for faience, which I had heard about before but didn't understand very well previously. It could be improved by spending less time on copper smelting and more on stone techniques. I think it would also be helpful to have the readings available earlier to give more time to read them. More hands on experience with the materials would also be beneficial.

There were just too many materials covered, and too much information on all of them, but this was the consensus when Professor Marouard asked everyone for feedback, so I'm sure the class will be more streamlined in future sessions. It's really cool that the class even exists, as the details of economic production and the lives of everyday people can often be relatively neglected in Egyptology relative to the language and monumental architecture.

The highlight of the class was a trip to the Wurtele Center to look at and handle Egyptian artifacts. It would be improved by handling more of the materials in person rather than just reading about them.

I think it would have been good to have some class time spent on what you are actually supposed to do when presenting your poster at a session, i.e. how much to talk versus let them read the poster.

Great informative material and powerpoints and room for student article presentations at the beginning. Could have used to spend a little less time on some individual topics to keep the course moving.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students in archaeology or history if they haven't had any background in the materials and methods of production in ancient times and cultures.
Yes if they were very interested in the exact techniques for ancient Egyptian production - no if not since the course was super super detailed
